choices.text:

Men are more likely to respond to avoidant styles of conflict (emotional availability and “agree to disagree” communication) coincidentally enabling the couple to assume more negative attitudes towards divorce when it does affect the family (Santos, 2012).

Conflict styles in marriages also play an important role in the effects it has on the children. Parental involvement is necessary to help children deal with the effects of emotional unavailability and/or frequent marital discord. Failing to have parent involvement by either one, or both, parents can lead to a higher likelihood for children to engage in violent behaviour, especially at a young age.

In my forthcoming monograph, entitled Family Law in Ghana, I emphasise the fact that mediation provides a good avenue for helping families to deal with their problems while contributing also to the socio-economic wellbeing of Ghana. Mediation in Ghana precedes statutory entry, partly, due to the principle of natural justice. Family matters are usually decided by relatives or other families of the parties. This situation works relatively well under the cultural norm of these societies. Generally, family relations under the qualitative basis would reflect the quality expressed in the cultural norms embraced by the society.

The traditional institution of mediation has high qualities in terms of being completely consensual and using multiple communication techniques to facilitate resolution of conflicts. However, this should be regarded more as an ad hoc practice and has not been able to capture the entire social system. This scenario
